articles.headline: Political Tumult in Greece After Uncertain Elections
articles.snippet: A day after the election, the prospect of the country leaving the euro zone loomed large.
articles.abstract: A day after the election, the prospect of the country leaving the euro zone loomed large.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece teetered on the verge of political chaos on Monday, with few signs that any party could form a governing coalition and the prospect of the nation leaving the euro zone looming increasingly large.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Abbott Settles Marketing Lawsuit
articles.snippet: Abbott Laboratories said it reached an agreement with the federal government and most states to pay $1.6 billion in connection with its marketing of the anti-seizure drug Depakote.
articles.abstract: Abbott Laboratories said it reached an agreement with the federal government and most states to pay $1.6 billion in connection with its marketing of the anti-seizure drug Depakote.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The pharmaceutical company Abbott Laboratories said on Monday that it had reached an agreement with the federal and nearly all state governments to pay $1.6 billion in connection with its illegal marketing of the anti-seizure drug Depakote.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Amazon Leaps Into High End of the Fashion Pool
articles.snippet: Amazon is taking on the high-end clothing business in its typical way: go big and spare no expense.
articles.abstract: Amazon is taking on the high-end clothing business in its typical way: go big and spare no expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon is so serious about its next big thing that it hired three women to do nothing but try on size 8 shoes for its Web reviews. Full time.

articles.headline: U.S. Jury Hands Google Mixed Verdict on Oracle
articles.snippet: A limited and split decision over copyright violations by Google all but guaranteed continuing litigation.
articles.abstract: A limited and split decision over copyright violations by Google all but guaranteed continuing litigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a split decision that all but guaranteed continuing litigation, a Federal District Court jury in San Francisco on Monday decided that Google infringed on the overall structure of software copyrights held by Oracle, but also said that Google had not violated other important parts of Oracle’s software known as Java.
articles.byline: By Quentin Hardy and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Liberals Steer Outside Money to Grass-Roots Organizing
articles.snippet: Major donors are preparing to inject $100 million into independent groups that plan to avoid the type of advertising campaigns financed by conservatives.
articles.abstract: Major donors are preparing to inject $100 million into independent groups that plan to avoid the type of advertising campaigns financed by conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months on the sidelines, major liberal donors including the financier George Soros are preparing to inject up to $100 million into independent groups to aid Democrats’ chances this fall. But instead of going head to head with the conservative “super PACs” and outside groups that have flooded the presidential and Congressional campaigns with negative advertising, the donors are focusing on grass-roots organizing, voter registration and Democratic turnout.

articles.headline: As Car Owners Downsize, the Market Is Strong for Their Used S.U.V.’s
articles.snippet: A few years ago, rising gasoline prices pretty much destroyed the market for the big trucks, but they have become popular again.
articles.abstract: A few years ago, rising gasoline prices pretty much destroyed the market for the big trucks, but they have become popular again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Car dealerships have many customers like David King, who traded in his 2007 Chevrolet Tahoe in late April because filling its 26-gallon tank with $4 gasoline had become so expensive. He now drives a Chevrolet Volt 25 miles each way to work, where he can charge the plug-in hybrid so it rarely uses any gas.

articles.headline: For a Blunt Biden, an Uneasy Supporting Role
articles.snippet: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s effort to subordinate his own voice to the broader enterprise has been a struggle, especially for a man who delights in speaking bluntly.
articles.abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s effort to subordinate his own voice to the broader enterprise has been a struggle, especially for a man who delights in speaking bluntly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama reviewed the comedy routine he was to deliver at the recent White House Correspondents’ Association dinner, one joke struck him as too hot. It suggested he might dump Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. from the ticket.

articles.headline: Steering Murdoch in Scandal, Klein Put School Goals Aside
articles.snippet: Six months after joining News Corporation to lead a push into the education market, Joel I. Klein became Rupert Murdoch’s legal compass in the phone-hacking scandal.
articles.abstract: Six months after joining News Corporation to lead a push into the education market, Joel I. Klein became Rupert Murdoch’s legal compass in the phone-hacking scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, after a British parliamentary report declared that Rupert Murdoch was “not a fit person” to lead a major corporation, several senior News Corporation executives huddled in tense discussion on the eighth floor of the company’s New York headquarters.

articles.headline: AMC Said to Be Talking to Chinese Buyer
articles.snippet: AMC Entertainment, which owns the second-largest movie theater chain in North America, is in talks to sell itself or a significant stake to one of China’s largest theater owners, according to those briefed on discussions.
articles.abstract: AMC Entertainment, which owns the second-largest movie theater chain in North America, is in talks to sell itself or a significant stake to one of China’s largest theater owners, according to those briefed on discussions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — AMC Entertainment, which owns the second-largest movie theater chain in North America, is in talks to sell the company or a significant stake in it to the Wanda Group, one of China’s largest theater owners, according to people briefed on the discussions.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Master Tactician in Israel Adds Power in a Coalition Deal
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu significantly expanded his power, creating the broadest coalition government in recent memory.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu significantly expanded his power, creating the broadest coalition government in recent memory.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Striking a secret deal with the leader of the opposition in the small morning hours, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel significantly expanded his power on Tuesday, creating the largest and broadest coalition government in recent memory, one that no single faction can topple.
